The system_id field is used to mark the storage system.
It will be assigned to self._state when run do_setup.
In _build_pool_stats method,It will be recorded by the pools information.

Volume migrate to host.The host may be another cinder volume node.
These hosts may be operating on the same storage system.

If the volume and the new host belong to the same storage system and pool,return directly and the storage system does not do anything.
If they belong to a different pool on the same system,the storage system will clone the volume into the new pool and return.
If they belong to different systems,We don't support this migration yet.

I agree.
I will correct it in the next patch.
Snapshot volumes should not be independent clones. Does the storage not support creating volumes directly from snapshots?

We are very sorry that our storage does not support creating volumes directly from a snapshot, because our snapshot is an incremental snapshot.
All snapshots in a volume share predefined space, and old snapshots depend on new snapshots.

So in our driver, I used the clone method for both cloning volumes and creating volumes from snapshots. The difference is that create volume from snapshot speacifies a snapshot clone, whereas a cloned volume is cloned using a temporarily allocated snapshot.

I know that some storage vendors use full-volume snapshots and can support the creation of volumes directly from the snapshot.However, both approaches are not usually supported.

pkg/ipam/ipam.go.message: or subnet overlaps with existing subnet?
shouldn't we be adding the range outside of this if block, so that it gets added regardless of whether the subnet exists?

this could be done as a later refactoring, but what do you think about a more hierarchical API:

1. add/get (idempotent) a subnet to an ipam
2. add/get (idempotent) a range to a subnet
3. allocate an to a range

Example:

ipam.GetSubnet(subnet).GetRange(range).AllocateIP()

where each API can have its own validation and can be used independently

Then Range would only need to track the last allocated ip in each range:

LastAllocated string

instead of needing to store a List of all IPs across all ranges, since they are allocated in order from Start to Stop within a range. finding the next ip to allocate becomes trivial (LastAllocated + 1, or Start if LastAllocated == nil)

If there is a need to get all IPs across all ranges, that could just be a getter:

ipam.GetSubnet(subnet).GetAllocatedIPs()
ipam.GetAllocatedIPs()

I like that approach, but the issue I think we'd (eventually) have with it is that although we can allocate IPs sequentially, they may become de-allocated non-sequentially.  I think we'll need the ability to re-allocate IPs that are "holes" in the sequential lists.  Also, it might be good to hard-fail if a request comes in asking for a range that's already in use (i.e. non-idempotent), to guard against e.g.  different subclusters accidentally requesting the same subnet ranges.
Makes sense. I guess the requestor will need to store whether its ip range has been reserved e.g. in a CRD status field, to avoid asking for it twice.
would be nice to have a NewRange(start, stop) constructor which validates that start <= stop.

valid concern, but I don't think this patch changes anything here - we'd continue to create a good bucket which would never update its timestamp because we'd only ever add responses with no timestamp.
There's a lot of overlap from buckets of errors and buckets with frags - this is a very small difference to keep in mind - it begs the question "when do we initialize with a timestamp vs. without"

For me ...

        timestamp_str = headers.get('X-Backend-Data-Timestamp',
                                    headers.get('X-Backend-Timestamp',
                                                headers.get('X-Timestamp')))

... works, and I could probably articulate what I imagine as some minor advantages.
That's (to my mind) a pretty big change in what timestamp_str means -- but maybe that's a good thing?

So I'm a little torn here -- on the one hand, "have timestamp and is not successful" seems way more direct/in line with the comment. On the other hand, I kind of liked the fact that with the flag, *the bucket is in charge*, rather than having this behavior depend upon what you end up putting *into* the bucket.

I found this comment "the bucket is in charge" particularly convincing.  I think my aversion to class sparwl was the only reason I didn't accept - "these two types are buckets are similar but different things"

Side note: I'm somewhat surprised that this didn't cause a TypeError on py3 before, but I guess we anticipated comparisons against None:

 >>> Timestamp.now() > None
 True
 >>> Timestamp.now() < None
 False
 >>> Timestamp(0) > None
 True
 >>> Timestamp(0) < None
 False
I feel like we're *so close* to being able to resolve this TODO...

makeing the flavor have precidence would break

"As an operator i wish to utilize numa aware vswitch but still be able to disable for individual vm interfaces."

We talked about this on the nova meeting today[1]. And I was convinced that this is less of a problem. Nova always prefer affinity regardless of the policy. Nova just not fail the boot if the policy allows suboptimal placement. So what the end user can do with the port base policy is to explicitly request / accept worse then optimal performance. 

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/nova/2021/nova.2021-01-21-16.00.log.html

hm, so the user can go against the admin's decision made in the flavor by creating a new port with specific numa_affinity_policy value. In telco space there is not much admin / tenant separation so meh. If others has no problem with this then I accept.

FWIW I agree it doesn't seem to sound right for a user to be able to override policy set by admin. If the port.numa_affinity_policy was an admin API by default, then that seems OK but if not, I have the same concern as gibi.

And it doesn't sound like giving precedence to the end user's choice is fulfilling the use case: "As an operator i wish to utilize numa aware vswitch but still be able to disable for individual vm interfaces." The operator has no ability to disable numa aware vswitch for individual interfaces in this model, right? How can the operator disable numa aware vswitch for an individual interface if the user can enable it on any port?

The operator has no ability to disable numa aware vswitch for individual interfaces in this model, right? Sean answered my questions regarding "disabling" affinity in #openstack-nova today and explained that the meaning of disable here is no affinity, not a prevention of affinity [1]. And that this should say "allow a tenant to disable it for individual VM interfaces."

I'm also OK after reading the discussion from the nova meeting that strict affinity is the default behavior and this feature would allow users to opt-in to accepting preferred/best effort affinity or no affinity. So there is no notion of a user being able to override and take resources that an admin has reserved, and that is why it is not problematic to allow users policy to take precendence.

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2021-01-21.log.html#t2021-01-21T20:40:01

so this is only used when dynamic credential prepare the admin service clients for creating the test user/projects right? what happen if the admin token is not scoped to system (mean this config option is None) and test try to create the system scoped user ?

In my testing patch, it pass without any issue- https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/devstack/+/614486/11//COMMIT_MSG#18

Yes this is only for dynamically creating other credentials, it doesn't anything about how the tests will run. It's the same as the admin_project_name option above, it's just the credentials of a preexisting admin user that has the ability to create other users. The purpose is to be able to run on a cloud where the admin user that tempest is configured to use only has a system-scoped role assignment and not a project-scoped role assignment. Tests could still create dynamic users that have project-scoped role assignments.

Here's an example of how it's used in the keystone tests: https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/src/branch/master/devstack/lib/scope.sh#L22-L26

enforce_scope is turned on in oslo_policy, the admin credentials are set to system scope and the project name is unset so that the user can only used the system-scoped credentials.

software vhost implementations have a performance overheard in comparison to SR-IOV or native nic performance yes.

Discussed this more on IRC. I think this is a pre-optimization and a stand-in for what we should be doing: PCI inventory in placement. What Sean says RE: limiting allocation candidates is true, but I think it's an edge case we're unlikely to hit and if we did, we could simply use provider.yaml to report a custom trait for hosts with vDPA inventory. I'd rather we dropped this trait for now and focused on adding PCI devices to placement next cycle. I'm not fervently against it though, so if anyone disagrees then I can live with this.

I don't think Sean is saying we'll report the version of libvirt and QEMU. Rather, they're saying that only compute nodes with a suitably new version of libvirt and QEMU will be able to support vDPA devices and therefore these hosts can report this trait to indicate that they have vDPA inventory. However, firstly that's kind of unnecessary to state, since if the hosts have vDPA inventory then they implicitly have a new enough libvirt and QEMU version (how else would they know that they're vDPA devices unless they had support for reading this device info). More importantly, I don't understand why we need this trait at all, since if the host didn't have a suitably new version of these packages or didn't have any vDPA devices then it simply wouldn't report any devices of type 'type-VDPA', which means the 'PciPassthroughFilter' would reject those hosts, right?

Later: I guess there is a the possibility that the 'PciPassthroughFilter' might not be enabled, in which case any host could be scheduled to and older hosts would explode when they encounter the 'type-VDPA' value. However, they're going to explode quite early when we attempt to downversion the o.vo, which I think is correct since requesting PCI devices, via neutron or otherwise, with this filter disabled is fundamentally a misconfiguration.
